summary: This document is a procedural guide by Da Rocha J. B. (SAG) on pre-trial matters under the High Court (Civil Procedure) Rules, LI 1129, in Ghana. It outlines key civil procedure principles including the proper joinder of parties, requirements for causes of action, and the role of persons under disability—such as infants or mentally incapacitated individuals—who must litigate through a next friend or guardian ad litem. The guide explains the issuance and service of writs, the necessity of appearance, and consequences of default. It also covers representative actions, third-party proceedings for indemnity or contribution, and the court's discretionary powers to manage cases fairly. The emphasis is on ensuring procedural correctness to avoid abuse of court processes and to uphold justice.
verdict: Not applicable – the document is a procedural commentary, not a court judgment.
citations: Aegis Shipping Co, Ltd v. Volta Line Ltd [1973] 1 GLR 438
rationaleHighlights: Proper joinder of parties ensures fair adjudication on common questions of law or fact.
A person under disability must litigate through a next friend or guardian ad litem to protect their interests.
The court has discretion to add, strike out, or substitute parties to prevent injustice.
A writ may be renewed to prevent statute-barred claims, but substituted service is often more practical.
Representative actions bind all class members unless fraud or collusion is proven.
confidenceNotes: The document is a procedural guide authored by Da Rocha J. B. (SAG), not a judicial decision, but reflects authoritative interpretation of civil procedure rules in Ghana. All information is consistent with High Court (Civil Procedure) Rules, LI 1129.
